decision_content.verbatim_text: The [Supplier ] shall not, during the term of this [Agreement] and for a period of [XX] months following the termination of this [Agreement], directly or indirectly, whether solely or jointly with any other person, and whether as principal, agent, director, officer, employee, shareholder, partner, joint venturer, adviser, consultant or otherwise: i. canvas, solicit or entice away (or attempt to do so) the [end-customer] of [Zebracorp]; ii. accept business in the same or similar field from the [end-customer of [Zebracorp]; or iii. attempt, counsel, procure or otherwise assist any person to do any of the acts referred to in this clause.
decision_content.plain_text: The Supplier must not, during the term of the Agreement and for a specified period of [XX] months following its termination, directly or indirectly, and in any capacity (e.g., as principal, agent, employee, consultant), solicit or entice away (or attempt to do so) Zebracorp's end-customers, accept business in the same or similar field from Zebracorp's end-customers, or assist others in performing any of these prohibited acts.
decision_content.expert_insight: This is a comprehensive non-solicitation and non-compete clause, critical for protecting Zebracorp's customer base and business interests. The broad scope of prohibited activities, roles, and the post-termination period aims to prevent any circumvention by the supplier and safeguard Zebracorp's customer relationships and intellectual property.
decision_content.conditions: Applies during the term of the Agreement and for a specified period of [XX] months following its termination. The prohibition covers direct or indirect actions and applies to the Supplier acting in various capacities (e.g., principal, agent, employee, consultant).
decision_content.justification: This clause is material to Zebracorp's decision to enter into the Agreement, fair and reasonable, and reasonably required to protect its commercial interests with its end-customers. Its sole purpose is to prevent the subcontractor from misusing information shared by Zebracorp and bypassing Zebracorp to offer services directly to its customers.
decision_content.implication_company: Zebracorp gains significant protection for its customer relationships and intellectual property related to customer requirements, preventing suppliers from poaching clients or leveraging information gained during the partnership.
decision_content.implication_supplier: The Supplier is strictly restricted from engaging with Zebracorp's end-customers in specific ways for a defined period, both during and after the contract, which limits their post-contractual business opportunities with those customers and carries severe consequences for non-compliance.
decision_content.source_insight: This is a direct quote from an example clause provided in the source text, highlighting a common restriction in project-specific supplier contract templates. The duration '[XX] months' is a placeholder that needs to be specified in the actual agreement.

decisions.rationale: Consensus: All agents agreed on the 'GUIDELINE' type and 'CRITICAL' classification. Evaluation: The verbatim text is a clear, self-sufficient contractual clause imposing specific prohibitions on the Supplier. It passes the Value Assessment as it is actionable and complete. The 'plain_text' has been consolidated to be comprehensive, covering the duration, scope (direct/indirect, various capacities), and the three specific prohibited actions. This guideline is critical for protecting Zebracorp's customer relationships and preventing unfair competition. It passes the Utility Check as it is highly specific and crucial for negotiation and risk management.

decision_content.verbatim_text: In addition to any other rights [Zebracorp] may have, if the [Supplier] breaches this clause, [Zebracorp]: i. will be entitled to be paid by the [Supplier] liquidated damages in the sum of [XXXXX USD]; and ii. may at its election terminate this [Agreement] with immediate effect, without incurring any liability, upon providing written notice to the [ Supplier].
decision_content.plain_text: If the Supplier breaches the non-solicitation clause, Zebracorp is entitled to be paid liquidated damages in the sum of [XXXXX USD] and may, at its election, terminate the Agreement immediately without incurring any liability, upon providing written notice to the Supplier. These remedies are in addition to any other rights Zebracorp may have.
decision_content.expert_insight: This clause outlines specific, severe consequences for a Supplier breaching the non-solicitation clause, providing Zebracorp with immediate financial compensation (liquidated damages) and the right to terminate the Agreement without liability. Liquidated damages clauses are critical for pre-estimating losses, simplifying damage claims, and deterring breaches, but must be a genuine pre-estimate of loss, not a penalty, to be enforceable.
decision_content.conditions: Applies if the Supplier breaches the non-solicitation clause (the restriction on approaching end customers).
decision_content.justification: To deter breaches, provide clear and immediate remedies for Zebracorp, and protect its commercial interests with its end-customers.
decision_content.implication_company: Zebracorp has clear, pre-defined, and actionable remedies (liquidated damages, immediate termination) in case of Supplier breach, simplifying enforcement and protecting its commercial interests.
decision_content.implication_supplier: The Supplier faces significant financial penalties ([XXXXX USD] liquidated damages) and the risk of immediate contract termination if they breach the non-solicitation clause, highlighting the critical nature of compliance.
decision_content.source_insight: The liquidated damages amount [XXXXX USD] needs to be specified. Zebracorp's right to terminate is 'at its election' and 'without incurring any liability'. Liquidated damages must be a genuine pre-estimate of loss, not a penalty, to be enforceable.

decisions.rationale: Consensus: All agents agreed on the 'GUIDELINE' type and 'CRITICAL' classification for this specific clause. Evaluation: The clause defines clear, actionable rights and obligations regarding remedies for a breach of the non-solicitation restriction. It passed the Clarity, Value, Necessity, and Utility checks. The plain_text has been contextualized to be self-sufficient. The cluster contained two distinct but related rules; due to the constraint of returning a single JSON object, the primary remedies clause (liquidated damages and termination) was selected as the Golden Record, as it represents the direct consequences of a breach. The 'without prejudice' clause, while critical, was deemed a clarification of these primary remedies.

decision_content.verbatim_text: Depending on the circumstances these type of restrictions may not be permitted under the applicable anti-trust/competition laws and for that reason it is essential to involve Legal & Compliance whenever contemplating on using these type of provisions. Note that these restrictions must to be cleared by Legal & Compliance in each case in order to ensure that the restrictions are not in violation of any laws and regulations dealing with anti-trust/fair competition.
decision_content.plain_text: Zebracorp must involve Legal & Compliance for review and obtain clearance in each individual case whenever contemplating or using customer restriction provisions, to ensure compliance with applicable anti-trust and fair competition laws and regulations.
decision_content.expert_insight: This is a paramount internal compliance guideline for Zebracorp. Restrictive covenants, particularly those limiting a supplier's interaction with end-customers, are highly scrutinized under anti-trust and competition laws. Failure to involve Legal & Compliance for case-by-case review and clearance can lead to severe penalties, fines, unenforceability of the clause, and significant legal and reputational risks. Proactive legal review is mandatory to ensure compliance and enforceability.
decision_content.conditions: Applies whenever Zebracorp is contemplating, drafting, or implementing customer restriction provisions in supplier contracts.
decision_content.justification: The source text explicitly states it is 'essential to involve' and 'must be cleared' by Legal & Compliance due to the high risk of non-compliance with anti-trust/competition laws, which can lead to severe legal and financial penalties.
decision_content.implication_company: Zebracorp has a mandatory internal process to follow, requiring Legal & Compliance involvement for every such clause. This is a critical risk mitigation step to ensure legal compliance, avoid penalties, and ensure the enforceability of contractual provisions.
decision_content.implication_supplier: The supplier indirectly benefits from legally compliant clauses, as they are more likely to be enforceable. However, the primary implication is for Zebracorp's internal process and risk management.
decision_content.source_insight: The text uses strong language ('essential', 'must be cleared') and highlights the variability ('Depending on the circumstances', 'in each case') to emphasize the critical, mandatory, and case-by-case nature of Legal & Compliance review due to anti-trust/competition law risks.

decisions.rationale: Consensus Check: Agents were split between 'GUIDELINE' and 'OTHER' (Instruction). The text describes a mandatory internal process for Zebracorp related to contract drafting, which creates a specific obligation for the company. Therefore, 'GUIDELINE' is the most appropriate classification, as it represents a critical operational rule for contract management. Value Assessment: The text is clear, self-sufficient, and provides essential context regarding the 'what', 'why', and 'who' for compliance. Type-Specific Criteria: As a GUIDELINE, it is highly actionable ('essential to involve', 'must be cleared') and complete. The classification as 'CRITICAL' is justified by the explicit mention of anti-trust/competition law violations and associated risks. Utility Check: This is a vital compliance requirement that helps Zebracorp mitigate significant legal and financial risks, making it highly valuable.

decision_content.verbatim_text: Passive sales, i.e. sales to the end customer that are not actively solicited by the subcontractor, but result from the end customer requesting a quotation from the subcontracting on its own initiative, should generally not be prohibited.
decision_content.plain_text: Customer restriction clauses should generally not prohibit passive sales, which are defined as sales to an end-customer initiated by the customer's own request for a quotation without active solicitation from the subcontractor.
decision_content.expert_insight: This is a critical guideline for competition law compliance. Prohibiting passive sales (where the end-customer initiates contact) is often considered a hardcore restriction under anti-trust laws, making such clauses potentially unenforceable or illegal. Zebracorp must ensure its non-solicitation clauses are narrowly tailored to allow for passive sales.
decision_content.conditions: Applies to customer restriction clauses where sales are passive, meaning they are not actively solicited by the subcontractor and result from the end customer's own initiative to request a quotation.
decision_content.justification: To ensure compliance with applicable anti-trust/competition laws, which generally view prohibitions on passive sales as anti-competitive and potentially illegal.
decision_content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure its contract templates and specific agreements do not prohibit passive sales to avoid legal challenges, non-compliance with competition law, and potential unenforceability of restriction clauses.
decision_content.implication_supplier: The Supplier generally retains the right to accept business from Zebracorp's end-customers if the customer initiates contact and requests a quotation without active solicitation from the Supplier, providing a limited but important business opportunity.
decision_content.source_insight: The text explicitly defines 'Passive sales' using 'i.e.' and then states they 'should generally not be prohibited,' indicating a strong recommendation for legal compliance. The word 'generally' suggests a default rule with potentially rare, specific exceptions, but the core principle remains.

decisions.rationale: Consensus: Mixed (3 GUIDELINE, 1 OTHER, 1 DEFINITION). Evaluation: The source text explicitly defines 'Passive sales' and immediately follows with a clear instruction that such sales 'should generally not be prohibited.' While a definition is present, its primary purpose within this sentence is to clarify the scope of the actionable rule. The instruction 'should generally not be prohibited' constitutes a specific, actionable obligation/restriction on contract drafting, particularly in the context of anti-trust/competition laws mentioned in the surrounding text. Therefore, the most appropriate classification is GUIDELINE, with the definition integrated into the plain_text and expert_insight for clarity. The finding passes the Value, Type-Specific, and Utility checks, as it is crucial for legal compliance and contract enforceability.

decision_content.verbatim_text: Note also that the duration of the restriction should always be limited and should never be extended from the time frames provided for in the templates.
decision_content.plain_text: The duration of customer restrictions must always be limited and should not exceed the time frames specified in standard templates.
decision_content.expert_insight: The reasonableness of the duration is a critical factor in the enforceability of restrictive covenants, particularly under competition law. Overly long periods are often deemed anti-competitive or unenforceable. Adhering to template durations provides a pre-vetted, reasonable benchmark, ensuring clauses remain legally sound and defensible.
decision_content.conditions: Applies when drafting or negotiating clauses that impose restrictions on suppliers approaching Zebracorp's end-customers.
decision_content.justification: This guideline is crucial to ensure the legal enforceability of customer restriction clauses and compliance with anti-trust/competition laws, which often scrutinize the reasonableness and duration of such provisions.
decision_content.implication_company: Zebracorp must strictly adhere to limited durations for customer restrictions, aligning with template time frames, to ensure legal validity, enforceability, and avoid challenges under competition law.
decision_content.implication_supplier: The Supplier is subject to a finite and clearly defined restriction period, based on established template durations, providing certainty regarding the extent of the limitation on approaching Zebracorp's end-customers.
decision_content.source_insight: The text explicitly uses strong directives ('should always be limited', 'should never be extended') and refers to 'time frames provided for in the templates,' indicating a firm internal policy and existing standards for duration.

decisions.rationale: Consensus Check: Four agents classified this as a GUIDELINE, while one classified it as OTHER (Instruction). The strong prescriptive language ('should always be limited', 'should never be extended') clearly indicates a specific rule or obligation for contract drafting, making GUIDELINE the most appropriate classification. Value Assessment: The plain text is clear and self-sufficient, providing a direct instruction on how to manage the duration of customer restrictions. It addresses a critical aspect of contract enforceability. Type-Specific Criteria (GUIDELINE): This is highly actionable, creating a specific obligation for contract drafters. It is not generic advice but a precise directive with significant legal implications. The information is complete as presented. Utility Check: This item is crucial for ensuring legal compliance and enforceability of restrictive covenants, directly impacting Zebracorp's commercial interests and legal risk. It helps prevent the drafting of unenforceable or anti-competitive clauses.

decision_content.verbatim_text: Most of the project specific supplier contract templates impose certain restrictions on the supplier approaching Zebracorp customers directly. Please see in e.g. Article 4.10 of the generic Subcontracting Agreement template.
decision_content.plain_text: Zebracorp's standard contract templates typically include clauses restricting suppliers from directly contacting Zebracorp's customers, as exemplified by Article 4.10 of the generic Subcontracting Agreement.
decision_content.expert_insight: This provides essential background, indicating that non-solicitation clauses are a standard and expected feature in Zebracorp's supplier contracts. It sets the baseline for discussions and negotiations, highlighting a common contractual practice to protect the primary contractor's customer relationships.
decision_content.justification: Provides general background information about the commonality and location of such clauses within Zebracorp's existing documentation.
decision_content.implication_company: Confirms that these types of clauses are standard practice for Zebracorp, reinforcing their importance and established nature in protecting its direct customer relationships.
decision_content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should anticipate these clauses in Zebracorp's contracts, indicating a consistent approach across projects and an expectation of restrictions on direct customer engagement.
decision_content.source_insight: Refers to a specific article (4.10) in a generic template, suggesting a structured and consistent approach to these restrictions.

decisions.rationale: Consensus: All agents agreed on 'OTHER' type with 'INFO' subtype. Evaluation: The verbatim text provides crucial background information regarding the standard inclusion of customer restriction clauses in Zebracorp's contracts, referencing a specific article (4.10) for context. This information is self-sufficient and highly valuable for setting expectations for both Zebracorp and its suppliers. The plain_text from Candidate 1 accurately captures the full context. Passed Utility check as it helps users understand the commonality and importance of these clauses. Classified as a high-priority 'OTHER' (INFO) finding.

decision_content.verbatim_text: It is important to note that the sole purpose of this restriction is merely to prevent the subcontractor from misusing the information that Zebracorp has shared on its customer requirements by offering the same scope of works directly to Zebracorpâ€™s customer in an attempt to bypass Zebracorp. These provisions are not intended to restrict competition between the parties but merely to safeguard Zebracorp existing customer relationship, and to prevent the subcontractor from taking improper advantage of the fact that Zebracorp considers subcontracting some of the customer scope to the subcontractor.
decision_content.plain_text: The sole purpose of these restrictions is to prevent subcontractors from misusing Zebracorp's shared customer information to bypass Zebracorp and directly offer the same scope of work to its customers. These provisions are not intended to restrict competition but rather to safeguard Zebracorp's existing customer relationships and prevent the subcontractor from taking improper advantage.
decision_content.expert_insight: This insight is crucial for legal interpretation and defense, particularly concerning anti-trust or competition law. It clarifies that the intent behind the non-solicitation clauses is to protect Zebracorp's proprietary information and existing customer relationships, not to restrict general competition. This understanding is vital for effective drafting, internal justification, and external defense during negotiations.
decision_content.justification: To clarify the legitimate business purpose of the non-solicitation restrictions, emphasizing the protection of Zebracorp's customer relationships and prevention of unfair advantage, rather than restricting competition.
decision_content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this stated purpose to defend the clauses against claims of anti-competitiveness and demonstrate legitimate business interest, strengthening its legal position.
decision_content.implication_supplier: Suppliers gain clarity on Zebracorp's motivation, understanding that the intent is to protect existing relationships and information, not to prevent all market engagement, which can aid in negotiations.
decision_content.source_insight: The text explicitly states the 'sole purpose' and 'intent' of the provisions, highlighting a key legal sensitivity regarding competition law.

decisions.rationale: Consensus: All agents agreed on 'OTHER' type with 'INFO' subtype and identical verbatim text. Value Assessment: The text provides crucial context and justification for the non-solicitation clauses, explaining their purpose as protective rather than anti-competitive. This is self-sufficient and highly valuable for legal defense and negotiation. Type-Specific Criteria: As an 'OTHER' (INFO) type, the content is well-contextualized and explains the 'what' and 'why' of the restrictions. Utility Check: This item is highly specific and helps in understanding the strategic intent, aiding in negotiation and legal compliance. Therefore, it is accepted as a critical piece of information.

decision_content.verbatim_text: Please see in e.g. Article 4.10 of the generic Subcontracting Agreement template.
decision_content.plain_text: An example of such a restriction can be found in Article 4.10 of the generic Subcontracting Agreement template.
decision_content.expert_insight: This provides a specific reference point for where such clauses are typically located within Zebracorp's standard agreements, guiding further investigation.
decision_content.implication_company: Standardized templates help ensure consistent application of these restrictions and provide a clear reference for internal teams.
decision_content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should review referenced articles in templates for specific details regarding restrictions.
decision_content.source_insight: The text explicitly points to this article as an example of the restrictions discussed.

decisions.rationale: Consensus: Agents agreed on the 'OTHER' type and 'EXAMPLE' subtype. Value Assessment: The verbatim text provides a clear, self-sufficient reference point for where to find examples of the discussed restrictions. The plain_text accurately contextualizes the reference. Type-Specific Criteria: It serves as a useful example/reference, not a rule or definition. Utility Check: This information is valuable as it directs users to specific articles in templates, aiding in understanding the practical application and location of such clauses. All checks passed.

decision_content.verbatim_text: The [Supplier] acknowledges that the covenants given in this clause are: i. material to [Zebracorp's] decision to enter into this [Agreement]; ii. fair and reasonable about the subject matter and duration; iii. provided in return for good and valuable consideration; and iv. reasonably required by [Zebracorp] to protect its commercial interests with its [endcustomer].
decision_content.plain_text: The Supplier acknowledges that the restrictive covenants in this clause are: i. material to Zebracorp's decision to enter the Agreement; ii. fair and reasonable regarding their subject matter and duration; iii. provided in return for good and valuable consideration; and iv. reasonably required by Zebracorp to protect its commercial interests with its end-customer.
decision_content.expert_insight: This acknowledgment clause is crucial for strengthening the enforceability of the restrictive covenants. By having the supplier explicitly agree to the materiality, reasonableness, and consideration, Zebracorp mitigates potential legal challenges to the validity of the clause. Such acknowledgements demonstrate mutual understanding and agreement on the necessity and fairness of the restrictions, which is particularly important in jurisdictions where such clauses are scrutinized.
decision_content.justification: To bolster the legal enforceability of the restrictive covenants by showing the supplier's explicit agreement to their importance, fairness, and necessity.
decision_content.implication_company: This acknowledgement provides Zebracorp with a stronger legal position, bolstering the enforceability of the restrictive covenants if they are challenged in court.
decision_content.implication_supplier: The supplier's explicit acknowledgment significantly weakens their ability to later challenge the validity or reasonableness of the restrictions.
decision_content.source_insight: Direct quote from an example clause.

decisions.rationale: Consensus: Agents agreed on the type (OTHER) and subtype (INFO), as well as the verbatim text. Value Assessment: The clause is a critical contractual mechanism that provides legal justification and strengthens the enforceability of the preceding restrictive covenants. It is self-sufficient in its explanation of what is being acknowledged. Type-Specific Criteria: It is not a guideline or a definition, but rather an informational clause that serves a specific legal purpose, making 'OTHER' with subtype 'INFO' appropriate. Utility Check: This finding is highly specific and helps a human understand the legal weight and purpose of such an acknowledgement, which is crucial for negotiation and risk assessment. It directly protects the company's commercial interests by bolstering enforceability.

content.verbatim_text: The [Supplier ] shall not, during the term of this [Agreement] and for a period of [XX] months following the termination of this [Agreement], directly or indirectly, whether solely or jointly with any other person, and whether as principal, agent, director, officer, employee, shareholder, partner, joint venturer, adviser, consultant or otherwise: i. canvas, solicit or entice away (or attempt to do so) the [end-customer] of [Zebracorp]; ii. accept business in the same or similar field from the [end-customer of [Zebracorp]; or iii. attempt, counsel, procure or otherwise assist any person to do any of the acts referred to in this clause.
content.plain_text: The Supplier must not, during the Agreement term and for a specified period post-termination, directly or indirectly solicit Zebracorp's end-customers, accept business from them in a similar field, or assist others in doing so.
content.expert_insight: This clause is crucial for protecting Zebracorp's customer base and preventing the Supplier from leveraging confidential information or relationships gained during the project to bypass Zebracorp. It's a standard protective measure in subcontracting agreements.
content.conditions: Applies during the term of the Agreement and for a specified period (e.g., [XX] months) following termination.
content.justification: This is a direct prohibition ('shall not') with significant commercial implications, protecting Zebracorp's core business interests. Its breach leads to severe penalties.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp gains protection for its customer relationships and intellectual property related to customer requirements.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier is restricted from engaging with Zebracorp's end-customers in specific ways for a defined period, limiting their post-contractual business opportunities with those customers.
content.source_insight: The clause covers various forms of engagement (direct/indirect, sole/joint, various roles) and three specific prohibited actions (canvas/solicit/entice, accept business, assist others). The duration [XX] needs to be specified.
content.text: The [Supplier ] shall not, during the term of this [Agreement] and for a period of [XX] months following the termination of this [Agreement], directly or indirectly, whether solely or jointly with any other person, and whether as principal, agent, director, officer, employee, shareholder, partner, joint venturer, adviser, consultant or otherwise: i. canvas, solicit or entice away (or attempt to do so) the [end-customer] of [Zebracorp]; ii. accept business in the same or similar field from the [end-customer of [Zebracorp]; or iii. attempt, counsel, procure or otherwise assist any person to do any of the acts referred to in this clause.

content.verbatim_text: In addition to any other rights [Zebracorp] may have, if the [Supplier] breaches this clause, [Zebracorp]: i. will be entitled to be paid by the [Supplier] liquidated damages in the sum of [XXXXX USD]; and ii. may at its election terminate this [Agreement] with immediate effect, without incurring any liability, upon providing written notice to the [ Supplier].
content.plain_text: If the Supplier breaches the non-solicitation clause, Zebracorp is entitled to liquidated damages and may terminate the Agreement immediately without liability.
content.expert_insight: These are critical remedies for Zebracorp, providing immediate financial compensation and the ability to exit the contract if the Supplier violates a fundamental protective clause. Liquidated damages clauses are important for pre-estimating losses and avoiding complex damage calculations.
content.conditions: Applies if the Supplier breaches the non-solicitation clause.
content.justification: This outlines severe, pre-defined consequences ('will be entitled', 'may at its election terminate') for a breach of a CRITICAL obligation, directly impacting financial and contractual stability.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp has clear, actionable remedies (liquidated damages, immediate termination) in case of Supplier breach, protecting its interests.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier faces significant financial penalties ([XXXXX USD] liquidated damages) and the risk of immediate contract termination if they breach the non-solicitation clause.
content.source_insight: The liquidated damages amount [XXXXX USD] needs to be specified. Zebracorp's right to terminate is 'at its election' and 'without incurring any liability'.
content.text: In addition to any other rights [Zebracorp] may have, if the [Supplier] breaches this clause, [Zebracorp]: i. will be entitled to be paid by the [Supplier] liquidated damages in the sum of [XXXXX USD]; and ii. may at its election terminate this [Agreement] with immediate effect, without incurring any liability, upon providing written notice to the [ Supplier].

content.verbatim_text: The [Supplier] acknowledges that the termination of this [Agreement] and/or the payment of any liquidated damages referred to in clause shall be without prejudice to and shall not preclude the right of [Zebracorp] to seek compensation for any other damages [Zebracorp] may incur as a result of any breach of this clause, and shall not relieve the [Supplier] of any of its obligations hereunder.
content.plain_text: Termination or payment of liquidated damages does not prevent Zebracorp from seeking additional compensation for other damages incurred due to the breach, nor does it relieve the Supplier of other obligations.
content.expert_insight: This clause is vital for Zebracorp to ensure that the specified remedies (liquidated damages, termination) are not exclusive and do not limit its ability to recover full losses or enforce other contractual terms. It prevents the Supplier from arguing that liquidated damages are the sole remedy.
content.conditions: Applies in the event of termination and/or payment of liquidated damages for a breach of the non-solicitation clause.
content.justification: This explicitly preserves Zebracorp's broader legal rights to seek full compensation and ensures the Supplier's ongoing obligations, reinforcing the severity and comprehensive nature of the breach consequences.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp retains the right to pursue all available legal remedies and compensation beyond liquidated damages, ensuring maximum protection.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier remains liable for all damages caused by the breach, even after paying liquidated damages or contract termination, and is not relieved of other contractual obligations.
content.source_insight: This clause strengthens Zebracorp's position by making the liquidated damages non-exclusive.
content.text: The [Supplier] acknowledges that the termination of this [Agreement] and/or the payment of any liquidated damages referred to in clause shall be without prejudice to and shall not preclude the right of [Zebracorp] to seek compensation for any other damages [Zebracorp] may incur as a result of any breach of this clause, and shall not relieve the [Supplier] of any of its obligations hereunder.

content.verbatim_text: Depending on the circumstances these type of restrictions may not be permitted under the applicable anti-trust/competition laws and for that reason it is essential to involve Legal & Compliance whenever contemplating on using these type of provisions. Note that these restrictions must to be cleared by Legal & Compliance in each case in order to ensure that the restrictions are not in violation of any laws and regulations dealing with anti-trust/fair competition.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp must involve Legal & Compliance for review and clearance whenever contemplating or using customer restriction provisions to ensure compliance with anti-trust/competition laws.
content.expert_insight: This is a paramount internal compliance guideline. Non-compete and non-solicitation clauses are highly scrutinized under competition law. Failure to comply can lead to severe penalties, fines, and unenforceability of the clause itself. Legal review is non-negotiable.
content.conditions: Applies whenever considering or implementing customer restriction provisions in contracts.
content.justification: Explicitly states 'essential to involve' and 'must be cleared' due to potential violations of 'anti-trust/competition laws,' which carry significant legal and financial risks.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure internal processes include mandatory Legal & Compliance review for these clauses, mitigating legal risks.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier (indirectly) benefits from legally compliant clauses, which are more likely to be enforceable, but the primary implication is for Zebracorp's internal process.
content.source_insight: The text emphasizes the importance due to potential anti-trust/competition law violations, using both 'essential' and 'must' language.
content.text: Depending on the circumstances these type of restrictions may not be permitted under the applicable anti-trust/competition laws and for that reason it is essential to involve Legal & Compliance whenever contemplating on using these type of provisions. Note that these restrictions must to be cleared by Legal & Compliance in each case in order to ensure that the restrictions are not in violation of any laws and regulations dealing with anti-trust/fair competition.

content.verbatim_text: Passive sales, i.e. sales to the end customer that are not actively solicited by the subcontractor, but result from the end customer requesting a quotation from the subcontracting on its own initiative, should generally not be prohibited.
content.plain_text: Customer restriction clauses should generally not prohibit passive sales, where the end-customer initiates contact with the Supplier without active solicitation.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial carve-out often required for competition law compliance. Overly broad prohibitions that restrict passive sales are more likely to be deemed anti-competitive and unenforceable. It allows the Supplier to respond to unsolicited inquiries.
content.conditions: Applies to the drafting and interpretation of customer restriction clauses.
content.justification: Uses 'should generally not be prohibited,' indicating a strong recommendation for legal compliance and enforceability, especially in the context of anti-trust concerns.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should ensure its restriction clauses are drafted to allow for passive sales, increasing their legal robustness and enforceability.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier retains the right to accept business from Zebracorp's end-customers if the customer initiates contact, providing a limited but important business opportunity.
content.source_insight: Defines 'passive sales' clearly. The term 'generally' suggests there might be very specific, rare exceptions, but the default rule is non-prohibition.
content.text: Passive sales, i.e. sales to the end customer that are not actively solicited by the subcontractor, but result from the end customer requesting a quotation from the subcontracting on its own initiative, should generally not be prohibited.

content.verbatim_text: Note also that the duration of the restriction should always be limited and should never be extended from the time frames provided for in the templates.
content.plain_text: The duration of customer restrictions must always be limited and should not exceed the time frames specified in standard templates.
content.expert_insight: Excessive duration is a common reason for non-compete/non-solicitation clauses to be deemed unenforceable under competition law. Limiting the duration to a reasonable period (often 12-24 months post-termination) is essential for enforceability and legal compliance.
content.conditions: Applies to the drafting of customer restriction clauses.
content.justification: Uses 'should always be limited' and 'should never be extended,' indicating a strong, mandatory guideline for legal enforceability and compliance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure its restriction clauses have reasonable and limited durations to enhance enforceability and comply with competition law.
content.implication_supplier: The Supplier benefits from a time-limited restriction, allowing them to eventually engage with Zebracorp's end-customers after a reasonable period.
content.source_insight: Refers to 'time frames provided for in the templates,' implying there are existing internal standards for duration.
content.text: Note also that the duration of the restriction should always be limited and should never be extended from the time frames provided for in the templates.

content.verbatim_text: Most of the project specific supplier contract templates impose certain restrictions on the supplier approaching Zebracorp customers directly. Please see in e.g. Article 4.10 of the generic Subcontracting Agreement template.
content.plain_text: Zebracorp's standard contract templates typically include clauses restricting suppliers from directly contacting Zebracorp's customers, as exemplified by Article 4.10 of the generic Subcontracting Agreement.
content.expert_insight: This provides essential background, indicating that non-solicitation clauses are a standard and expected feature in Zebracorp's supplier contracts. It sets the baseline for discussions and negotiations.
content.justification: Provides general background information about the commonality and location of such clauses within Zebracorp's existing documentation.
content.implication_company: Confirms that these types of clauses are standard practice for Zebracorp, reinforcing their importance and established nature.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should anticipate these clauses in Zebracorp's contracts, indicating a consistent approach across projects.
content.source_insight: Refers to a specific article (4.10) in a generic template, suggesting a structured and consistent approach to these restrictions.
content.text: Most of the project specific supplier contract templates impose certain restrictions on the supplier approaching Zebracorp customers directly. Please see in e.g. Article 4.10 of the generic Subcontracting Agreement template.

content.verbatim_text: It is important to note that the sole purpose of this restriction is merely to prevent the subcontractor from misusing the information that Zebracorp has shared on its customer requirements by offering the same scope of works directly to Zebracorpâ€™s customer in an attempt to bypass Zebracorp. These provisions are not intended to restrict competition between the parties but merely to safeguard Zebracorp existing customer relationship, and to prevent the subcontractor from taking improper advantage of the fact that Zebracorp considers subcontracting some of the customer scope to the subcontractor.
content.plain_text: The primary goal of these restrictions is to prevent subcontractors from using Zebracorp's shared customer information to bypass Zebracorp and directly solicit its customers for the same work. They are not meant to limit competition but to protect Zebracorp's customer relationships and prevent improper advantage-taking.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial piece of strategic context. Understanding the 'why' behind the clause allows for more effective drafting, internal justification, and external defense during negotiations. It explicitly clarifies that the intent is not anti-competitive, which is vital for legal compliance.
content.justification: Explains the strategic rationale and intent behind the non-solicitation clauses, which is crucial for internal understanding and external justification during negotiations.
content.implication_company: Provides a clear, defensible reason for including these clauses, which can be used to counter arguments about anti-competitive practices and demonstrate legitimate business interest.
content.implication_supplier: Helps suppliers understand Zebracorp's motivation, potentially making the clause more palatable if its scope is clearly defined and its purpose understood.
content.source_insight: The explicit statement that 'These provisions are not intended to restrict competition' is a key nuance, highlighting a potential legal sensitivity and Zebracorp's stance on it.
content.text: It is important to note that the sole purpose of this restriction is merely to prevent the subcontractor from misusing the information that Zebracorp has shared on its customer requirements by offering the same scope of works directly to Zebracorpâ€™s customer in an attempt to bypass Zebracorp. These provisions are not intended to restrict competition between the parties but merely to safeguard Zebracorp existing customer relationship, and to prevent the subcontractor from taking improper advantage of the fact that Zebracorp considers subcontracting some of the customer scope to the subcontractor.

content.verbatim_text: Depending on the circumstances these type of restrictions may not be permitted under the applicable anti-trust/competition laws and for that reason it is essential to involve Legal & Compliance whenever contemplating on using these type of provisions.
content.plain_text: Due to potential conflicts with anti-trust/competition laws, it is mandatory to consult Legal & Compliance before implementing such restrictions.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical, non-negotiable internal process instruction. It flags a high-risk area that requires expert legal review to ensure enforceability and compliance, mitigating significant legal and reputational risks.
content.justification: Highlights a critical compliance requirement due to legal risks associated with anti-trust/competition laws, necessitating expert review.
content.implication_company: Failure to involve Legal & Compliance could lead to significant legal penalties, fines, and reputational damage, making this a mandatory step.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers might challenge these clauses on anti-trust grounds, making prior legal review essential for Zebracorp to ensure defensibility.
content.source_insight: The phrase 'Depending on the circumstances' indicates variability in legal permissibility, reinforcing the need for case-by-case review rather than a blanket application.
content.text: Depending on the circumstances these type of restrictions may not be permitted under the applicable anti-trust/competition laws and for that reason it is essential to involve Legal & Compliance whenever contemplating on using these type of provisions.

content.verbatim_text: Passive sales, i.e. sales to the end customer that are not actively solicited by the subcontractor, but result from the end customer requesting a quotation from the subcontracting on its own initiative, should generally not be prohibited.
content.plain_text: Sales to end customers that occur passively (i.e., initiated by the customer, not actively solicited by the subcontractor) should generally be permitted.
content.expert_insight: This is a key distinction in competition law. Allowing passive sales often makes a non-solicitation clause more defensible and less likely to be challenged as anti-competitive. It provides a practical guideline for drafting and negotiation to ensure compliance and reasonableness.
content.justification: Provides a guideline for what types of sales should not be restricted, which is important for balancing Zebracorp's protection with competition law compliance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should ensure its clauses do not inadvertently prohibit passive sales, as this could be seen as anti-competitive and undermine the clause's enforceability.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers can use this point to argue against overly broad non-solicitation clauses, ensuring they are not unduly restricted from legitimate business opportunities.
content.source_insight: The word 'generally' implies there might be rare exceptions, but the default position is clear: passive sales should be allowed.
content.text: Passive sales, i.e. sales to the end customer that are not actively solicited by the subcontractor, but result from the end customer requesting a quotation from the subcontracting on its own initiative, should generally not be prohibited.

content.verbatim_text: Note also that the duration of the restriction should always be limited and should never be extended from the time frames provided for in the templates.
content.plain_text: The duration of any restriction must always be limited and should not exceed the timeframes specified in standard templates.
content.expert_insight: Duration is a critical factor in the enforceability of restrictive covenants. Overly long periods are often struck down by courts. This instruction provides a clear boundary for negotiators, ensuring clauses remain reasonable and legally sound.
content.justification: Provides a clear guideline for drafting and negotiating the duration of the restriction, which is a common point of contention and legal scrutiny.
content.implication_company: Adhering to limited durations helps ensure enforceability and compliance with competition laws, preventing clauses from being deemed unreasonable.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers will likely push for shorter durations, and Zebracorp has an internal guideline not to exceed template limits, providing a clear negotiation boundary.
content.source_insight: 'Should always be limited' and 'should never be extended' are strong directives, indicating a firm policy on duration.
content.text: Note also that the duration of the restriction should always be limited and should never be extended from the time frames provided for in the templates.

content.verbatim_text: Note that these restrictions must to be cleared by Legal & Compliance in each case in order to ensure that the restrictions are not in violation of any laws and regulations dealing with anti-trust/fair competition.
content.plain_text: All such restrictions require case-by-case clearance from Legal & Compliance to ensure compliance with anti-trust and fair competition laws.
content.expert_insight: This reiteration underscores the high importance and mandatory nature of legal review for these types of clauses, especially given the anti-trust implications. It acts as a crucial double-check mechanism to ensure ongoing compliance.
content.justification: Reinforces the critical internal process step for legal compliance, emphasizing the 'each case' aspect due to the dynamic nature of competition law.
content.implication_company: This is a mandatory step to mitigate legal risks and ensure the enforceability of the clauses, protecting Zebracorp from potential legal challenges.
content.implication_supplier: Zebracorp's internal process ensures that the clauses presented to suppliers have been vetted for legal compliance, adding credibility to the terms.
content.source_insight: The phrase 'in each case' highlights that a blanket approval is insufficient; individual circumstances and evolving legal landscapes must be considered for every instance.
content.text: Note that these restrictions must to be cleared by Legal & Compliance in each case in order to ensure that the restrictions are not in violation of any laws and regulations dealing with anti-trust/fair competition.

content.verbatim_text: â€œThe [Supplier ] shall not, during the term of this [Agreement] and for a period of [XX] months following the termination of this [Agreement], directly or indirectly, whether solely or jointly with any other person, and whether as principal, agent, director, officer, employee, shareholder, partner, joint venturer, adviser, consultant or otherwise: i. canvas, solicit or entice away (or attempt to do so) the [end-customer] of [Zebracorp]; ii. accept business in the same or similar field from the [end-customer of [Zebracorp]; or iii. attempt, counsel, procure or otherwise assist any person to do any of the acts referred to in this clause.
content.plain_text: During the agreement term and for a specified period post-termination (XX months), the Supplier must not, directly or indirectly, in any capacity (e.g., as principal, agent, employee, consultant), solicit or entice Zebracorp's end-customers, accept business from them in similar fields, or assist others in doing so.
content.expert_insight: This is a comprehensive non-solicitation and non-compete clause designed to protect Zebracorp's customer base. The broad scope of 'directly or indirectly' and 'in any capacity' aims to prevent circumvention. The post-termination period is crucial for continued protection.
content.conditions: Applies during the term of the Agreement and for [XX] months following its termination. Applies to direct or indirect actions, and to the Supplier acting in various capacities (e.g., principal, agent, employee, consultant).
content.justification: To prevent the supplier from misusing information shared by Zebracorp and bypassing Zebracorp to offer services directly to its customers.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp gains protection for its customer relationships and intellectual property related to customer requirements. It provides a legal basis to prevent suppliers from poaching clients.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier is severely restricted from engaging with Zebracorp's end-customers for a significant period, both during and after the contract. This impacts their ability to grow their business with Zebracorp's clients.
content.source_insight: Direct quote from an example clause.
content.text: â€œThe [Supplier ] shall not, during the term of this [Agreement] and for a period of [XX] months following the termination of this [Agreement], directly or indirectly, whether solely or jointly with any other person, and whether as principal, agent, director, officer, employee, shareholder, partner, joint venturer, adviser, consultant or otherwise: i. canvas, solicit or entice away (or attempt to do so) the [end-customer] of [Zebracorp]; ii. accept business in the same or similar field from the [end-customer of [Zebracorp]; or iii. attempt, counsel, procure or otherwise assist any person to do any of the acts referred to in this clause.

content.verbatim_text: The [Supplier] acknowledges that the covenants given in this clause are: i. material to [Zebracorp's] decision to enter into this [Agreement]; ii. fair and reasonable about the subject matter and duration; iii. provided in return for good and valuable consideration; and iv. reasonably required by [Zebracorp] to protect its commercial interests with its [endcustomer].
content.plain_text: The Supplier acknowledges that these restrictions are fundamental to Zebracorp's decision to enter the agreement, are fair and reasonable, are supported by valuable consideration, and are necessary for Zebracorp to protect its commercial interests.
content.expert_insight: Such acknowledgements are often included to strengthen the enforceability of restrictive covenants by demonstrating mutual understanding and agreement on their necessity and fairness, especially in jurisdictions where such clauses are scrutinized.
content.justification: To bolster the legal enforceability of the restrictive covenants by showing the supplier's explicit agreement to their importance, fairness, and necessity.
content.implication_company: This acknowledgement clause provides a stronger legal position for Zebracorp if the restrictions are challenged in court.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier's ability to later challenge the validity or reasonableness of the restrictions is significantly weakened by this explicit acknowledgement.
content.source_insight: Direct quote from an example clause.
content.text: The [Supplier] acknowledges that the covenants given in this clause are: i. material to [Zebracorp's] decision to enter into this [Agreement]; ii. fair and reasonable about the subject matter and duration; iii. provided in return for good and valuable consideration; and iv. reasonably required by [Zebracorp] to protect its commercial interests with its [endcustomer].

content.verbatim_text: In addition to any other rights [Zebracorp] may have, if the [Supplier] breaches this clause, [Zebracorp]: i. will be entitled to be paid by the [Supplier] liquidated damages in the sum of [XXXXX USD]; and ii. may at its election terminate this [Agreement] with immediate effect, without incurring any liability, upon providing written notice to the [ Supplier].
content.plain_text: If the Supplier breaches this clause, Zebracorp is entitled to liquidated damages of [XXXXX USD] and may immediately terminate the agreement without liability by providing written notice, in addition to any other rights it may have.
content.expert_insight: This outlines specific, severe consequences for breach, including a pre-determined financial penalty (liquidated damages) and immediate termination rights. Liquidated damages clauses are intended to provide a clear remedy without needing to prove actual damages, but must be a genuine pre-estimate of loss, not a penalty.
content.conditions: Breach of the non-solicitation/non-compete clause by the Supplier.
content.justification: To deter breaches and provide clear, immediate remedies for Zebracorp in case of non-compliance.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp has clear, pre-defined remedies for a breach, simplifying enforcement and providing financial compensation and immediate termination rights.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier faces significant financial penalties and immediate contract termination if they breach the clause, highlighting the critical nature of compliance.
content.source_insight: Direct quote from an example clause.
content.text: In addition to any other rights [Zebracorp] may have, if the [Supplier] breaches this clause, [Zebracorp]: i. will be entitled to be paid by the [Supplier] liquidated damages in the sum of [XXXXX USD]; and ii. may at its election terminate this [Agreement] with immediate effect, without incurring any liability, upon providing written notice to the [ Supplier].

content.verbatim_text: The [Supplier] acknowledges that the termination of this [Agreement] and/or the payment of any liquidated damages referred to in clause shall be without prejudice to and shall not preclude the right of [Zebracorp] to seek compensation for any other damages [Zebracorp] may incur as a result of any breach of this clause, and shall not relieve the [Supplier] of any of its obligations hereunder.â€
content.plain_text: The Supplier acknowledges that termination or payment of liquidated damages does not prevent Zebracorp from seeking additional compensation for other damages incurred due to the breach, nor does it relieve the Supplier of other contractual obligations.
content.expert_insight: This 'without prejudice' clause is critical. It clarifies that the specified remedies (termination, liquidated damages) are not exhaustive and Zebracorp retains the right to pursue further claims for actual damages beyond the liquidated sum, and the supplier remains bound by other contractual duties.
content.conditions: Breach of the non-solicitation/non-compete clause by the Supplier.
content.justification: To ensure that Zebracorp's remedies are not limited to liquidated damages and termination, and to preserve its right to full compensation for all losses.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp retains maximum flexibility to recover all damages suffered due to a breach, and the liquidated damages are viewed as a minimum, not a cap.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier faces potentially unlimited liability for damages resulting from a breach, even after paying liquidated damages or having the contract terminated.
content.source_insight: Direct quote from an example clause.
content.text: The [Supplier] acknowledges that the termination of this [Agreement] and/or the payment of any liquidated damages referred to in clause shall be without prejudice to and shall not preclude the right of [Zebracorp] to seek compensation for any other damages [Zebracorp] may incur as a result of any breach of this clause, and shall not relieve the [Supplier] of any of its obligations hereunder.â€

content.verbatim_text: It is important to note that the sole purpose of this restriction is merely to prevent the subcontractor from misusing the information that Zebracorp has shared on its customer requirements by offering the same scope of works directly to Zebracorpâ€™s customer in an attempt to bypass Zebracorp. These provisions are not intended to restrict competition between the parties but merely to safeguard Zebracorp existing customer relationship, and to prevent the subcontractor from taking improper advantage of the fact that Zebracorp considers subcontracting some of the customer scope to the subcontractor.
content.plain_text: The primary goal of these restrictions is to prevent subcontractors from leveraging confidential customer information shared by Zebracorp to bypass Zebracorp and directly offer services to its customers. They are designed to protect Zebracorp's customer relationships, not to stifle fair competition.
content.expert_insight: This provides critical insight into the *intent* behind the clauses. Articulating this intent can be vital in legal challenges, particularly concerning anti-trust or competition law, as it frames the clause as protective rather than anti-competitive.
content.justification: To clarify the legitimate business purpose of the restrictions, which is to protect Zebracorp's customer relationships and prevent unfair advantage, not to restrict competition.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp can use this stated purpose to defend the clauses against claims of anti-competitiveness.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers should understand that the intent is to protect Zebracorp's existing relationships, not to prevent all engagement with the market.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states the 'sole purpose' and 'intent' of the provisions.
content.text: It is important to note that the sole purpose of this restriction is merely to prevent the subcontractor from misusing the information that Zebracorp has shared on its customer requirements by offering the same scope of works directly to Zebracorpâ€™s customer in an attempt to bypass Zebracorp. These provisions are not intended to restrict competition between the parties but merely to safeguard Zebracorp existing customer relationship, and to prevent the subcontractor from taking improper advantage of the fact that Zebracorp considers subcontracting some of the customer scope to the subcontractor.

content.verbatim_text: Depending on the circumstances these type of restrictions may not be permitted under the applicable anti-trust/competition laws and for that reason it is essential to involve Legal & Compliance whenever contemplating on using these type of provisions.

content.expert_insight: This is a crucial compliance warning. Restrictive covenants, especially non-compete clauses, are heavily scrutinized under competition law. Failure to comply can lead to severe penalties. Legal & Compliance review is non-negotiable.
content.conditions: Contemplating on using restrictive provisions in supplier contracts.
content.justification: To ensure compliance with anti-trust/competition laws and avoid legal challenges or penalties.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure all such clauses are legally sound and compliant; failure to do so can result in significant legal and financial repercussions.

content.verbatim_text: Passive sales, i.e. sales to the end customer that are not actively solicited by the subcontractor, but result from the end customer requesting a quotation from the subcontracting on its own initiative
content.plain_text: Passive sales are sales made to an end customer who initiates contact and requests a quotation from the subcontractor, without active solicitation by the subcontractor.
content.expert_insight: This distinction is critical in competition law, as prohibiting passive sales is often considered a hardcore restriction and highly anti-competitive, whereas prohibiting active sales might be permissible under certain conditions.

content.verbatim_text: Passive sales, i.e. sales to the end customer that are not actively solicited by the subcontractor, but result from the end customer requesting a quotation from the subcontracting on its own initiative, should generally not be prohibited.
content.plain_text: Generally, passive sales (where the customer initiates contact) by the subcontractor to the end customer should not be prohibited.
content.expert_insight: Prohibiting passive sales is often viewed as a serious anti-competitive practice under competition law, which could lead to clauses being deemed unenforceable or even result in fines. This guideline advises against such prohibitions.
content.conditions: Sales are passive (i.e., initiated by the end customer without active solicitation from the subcontractor).
content.justification: To avoid violating anti-trust/competition laws, which typically view prohibitions on passive sales as highly restrictive.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp should ensure its contracts do not prohibit passive sales to avoid legal challenges and non-compliance with competition law.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers generally retain the right to accept business from Zebracorp's end-customers if those customers initiate contact, even if other forms of solicitation are restricted.
content.source_insight: The text explicitly states that passive sales 'should generally not be prohibited'.

content.verbatim_text: Note also that the duration of the restriction should always be limited and should never be extended from the time frames provided for in the templates.

content.justification: To ensure the restrictions remain legally defensible and do not become overly burdensome or anti-competitive.

content.verbatim_text: â€œThe [Supplier ] shall not, during the term of this [Agreement] and for a period of [XX] months following the termination of this [Agreement], directly or indirectly, whether solely or jointly with any other person, and whether as principal, agent, director, officer, employee, shareholder, partner, joint venturer, adviser, consultant or otherwise: i. canvas, solicit or entice away (or attempt to do so) the [end-customer] of [Zebracorp]; ii. accept business in the same or similar field from the [end-customer of [Zebracorp]; or iii. attempt, counsel, procure or otherwise assist any person to do any of the acts referred to in this clause.
content.plain_text: During the term of the Agreement and for a period of [XX] months after its termination, the Supplier is prohibited from, directly or indirectly, in any capacity (e.g., principal, agent, employee): i. soliciting or attempting to solicit Zebracorp's end-customers; ii. accepting business in a similar field from Zebracorp's end-customers; or iii. assisting any third party in performing these prohibited acts.
content.expert_insight: This is a comprehensive non-solicitation and non-compete clause, critical for protecting Zebracorp's customer base and business interests. The broad scope of prohibited activities and roles aims to prevent any circumvention by the supplier.

content.justification: To protect Zebracorp's customer relationships and prevent the supplier from misusing shared information or bypassing Zebracorp.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp protects its customer base and prevents direct competition from its suppliers using information gained through the partnership.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier faces strict prohibitions on engaging with Zebracorp's end-customers for a defined period, both during and after the contract, with potential severe consequences for non-compliance.

content.implication_supplier: The supplier's explicit acknowledgment makes it harder to later challenge the validity or reasonableness of the restrictions.

content.text: The [Supplier] acknowledges that the covenants given in this clause are: i. material to [Zebracorp's] decision to enter into this [Agreement]; ii. fair and reasonable about the subject matter and duration; iii. provided in return for good and valuable consideration; and iv. reasonably required by [Zebracorp] to protect its commercial interests with its [endcustomer].

content.verbatim_text: In addition to any other rights [Zebracorp] may have, if the [Supplier] breaches this clause, [Zebracorp]: i. will be entitled to be paid by the [Supplier] liquidated damages in the sum of [XXXXX USD]; and ii. may at its election terminate this [Agreement] with immediate effect, without incurring any liability, upon providing written notice to the [ Supplier].
content.plain_text: If the Supplier breaches this clause, Zebracorp is entitled to liquidated damages of [XXXXX USD] and may, at its discretion, terminate the Agreement immediately without liability, upon written notice to the Supplier. These remedies are in addition to any other rights Zebracorp may have.
content.expert_insight: This outlines the immediate and significant consequences for a supplier breaching the non-solicitation clause, providing Zebracorp with clear financial and contractual recourse. Liquidated damages clauses aim to pre-estimate and simplify damage claims, but must be a genuine pre-estimate, not a penalty, to be enforceable.
content.conditions: Breach of the restriction clause by the Supplier.
content.justification: To deter breaches and compensate Zebracorp for damages caused by a breach of the customer approach restriction.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp has defined remedies, including financial compensation and immediate contract termination rights, in case of supplier non-compliance, protecting its interests.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier faces significant financial penalties (liquidated damages) and immediate contract termination if the restriction is violated, highlighting the seriousness of the obligation.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: In addition to any other rights [Zebracorp] may have, if the [Supplier] breaches this clause, [Zebracorp]: i. will be entitled to be paid by the [Supplier] liquidated damages in the sum of [XXXXX USD]; and ii. may at its election terminate this [Agreement] with immediate effect, without incurring any liability, upon providing written notice to the [ Supplier].

content.verbatim_text: The [Supplier] acknowledges that the termination of this [Agreement] and/or the payment of any liquidated damages referred to in clause shall be without prejudice to and shall not preclude the right of [Zebracorp] to seek compensation for any other damages [Zebracorp] may incur as a result of any breach of this clause, and shall not relieve the [Supplier] of any of its obligations hereunder.â€
content.plain_text: The Supplier acknowledges that contract termination or payment of liquidated damages does not prevent Zebracorp from seeking additional compensation for any other damages incurred due to the breach, nor does it relieve the Supplier of other existing contractual obligations.
content.expert_insight: This 'without prejudice' clause ensures that the specified remedies (termination, liquidated damages) are not exhaustive and do not limit Zebracorp's ability to pursue full compensation for all losses, nor do they excuse the supplier from other contractual duties. This is a standard protective measure for the aggrieved party.
content.justification: To ensure Zebracorp's full right to compensation for all damages and to maintain the supplier's other contractual obligations despite a breach.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp retains the right to pursue full compensation for all damages incurred due to a breach, even if liquidated damages are paid or the contract is terminated.
content.implication_supplier: Payment of liquidated damages or contract termination does not cap liability; the supplier may still be liable for further damages and must fulfill other obligations.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: The [Supplier] acknowledges that the termination of this [Agreement] and/or the payment of any liquidated damages referred to in clause shall be without prejudice to and shall not preclude the right of [Zebracorp] to seek compensation for any other damages [Zebracorp] may incur as a result of any breach of this clause, and shall not relieve the [Supplier] of any of its obligations hereunder.â€

content.verbatim_text: It is important to note that the sole purpose of this restriction is merely to prevent the subcontractor from misusing the information that Zebracorp has shared on its customer requirements by offering the same scope of works directly to Zebracorpâ€™s customer in an attempt to bypass Zebracorp. These provisions are not intended to restrict competition between the parties but merely to safeguard Zebracorp existing customer relationship, and to prevent the subcontractor from taking improper advantage of the fact that Zebracorp considers subcontracting some of the customer scope to the subcontractor.
content.plain_text: The primary purpose of this restriction is to prevent subcontractors from misusing Zebracorp's customer information to bypass Zebracorp and directly offer similar services. It aims to safeguard Zebracorp's customer relationships and prevent improper advantage, not to restrict general competition.
content.expert_insight: This clarification of purpose is vital for legal interpretation, especially in the context of anti-trust or competition law. By framing the restriction as a protection of proprietary information and customer relationships, rather than a general restraint on trade, Zebracorp strengthens its legal position.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Provides a strong legal basis for the restriction, emphasizing protection of confidential information and customer relationships over anti-competitive intent.
content.implication_supplier: Helps the supplier understand the underlying rationale for the restriction, which is rooted in protecting Zebracorp's specific commercial interests.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: It is important to note that the sole purpose of this restriction is merely to prevent the subcontractor from misusing the information that Zebracorp has shared on its customer requirements by offering the same scope of works directly to Zebracorpâ€™s customer in an attempt to bypass Zebracorp. These provisions are not intended to restrict competition between the parties but merely to safeguard Zebracorp existing customer relationship, and to prevent the subcontractor from taking improper advantage of the fact that Zebracorp considers subcontracting some of the customer scope to the subcontractor.

content.verbatim_text: Depending on the circumstances these type of restrictions may not be permitted under the applicable anti-trust/competition laws and for that reason it is essential to involve Legal & Compliance whenever contemplating on using these type of provisions.
content.plain_text: Due to potential conflicts with anti-trust/competition laws, it is essential to involve Legal & Compliance whenever considering the use of such restrictive provisions.
content.expert_insight: This is a critical warning. Overly broad or lengthy restrictions can be deemed anti-competitive and unenforceable, leading to significant legal and financial penalties. Proactive legal review is mandatory to ensure compliance.
content.justification: N/A
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure strict adherence to anti-trust/competition laws when drafting or implementing such clauses to avoid legal challenges and penalties.
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Depending on the circumstances these type of restrictions may not be permitted under the applicable anti-trust/competition laws and for that reason it is essential to involve Legal & Compliance whenever contemplating on using these type of provisions.

content.verbatim_text: Passive sales, i.e. sales to the end customer that are not actively solicited by the subcontractor, but result from the end customer requesting a quotation from the subcontracting on its own initiative, should generally not be prohibited.
content.plain_text: Passive sales, defined as sales to an end-customer initiated by the customer's own request for a quotation without active solicitation from the subcontractor, should generally not be prohibited.
content.expert_insight: This is a crucial distinction in competition law. Prohibiting passive sales can be considered a hardcore restriction under anti-trust laws, making the entire clause (or agreement) illegal. Clauses must be carefully drafted to allow for passive sales.
content.conditions: Sales must be 'passive' (not actively solicited by the supplier) and initiated by the end customer on their own initiative.
content.justification: To ensure compliance with anti-trust/competition laws, which generally permit passive sales.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must ensure its non-solicitation clauses are narrowly tailored to allow for passive sales, or risk violating anti-trust laws.
content.implication_supplier: Suppliers are generally permitted to accept business from Zebracorp's end-customers if the customer initiates contact without active solicitation from the supplier.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Passive sales, i.e. sales to the end customer that are not actively solicited by the subcontractor, but result from the end customer requesting a quotation from the subcontracting on its own initiative, should generally not be prohibited.

content.verbatim_text: Note also that the duration of the restriction should always be limited and should never be extended from the time frames provided for in the templates.
content.plain_text: The duration of any restriction must always be limited and should not exceed the time frames specified in standard templates.
content.expert_insight: The reasonableness of a restriction's duration is a key factor in its enforceability under competition law. Overly long restrictions are often deemed unenforceable. Adhering to template durations provides a benchmark for reasonableness.
content.justification: To ensure enforceability and compliance with legal requirements, as anti-trust laws often scrutinize the reasonableness of restriction durations.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp must adhere to reasonable and limited durations for restrictions to ensure their legal validity and avoid challenges.
content.implication_supplier: The supplier's restriction period is finite and based on established template durations, providing clarity on the extent of the limitation.
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Note also that the duration of the restriction should always be limited and should never be extended from the time frames provided for in the templates.

content.verbatim_text: Note that these restrictions must to be cleared by Legal & Compliance in each case in order to ensure that the restrictions are not in violation of any laws and regulations dealing with anti-trust/fair competition.
content.plain_text: All such restrictions must be cleared by Legal & Compliance in each individual case to ensure compliance with anti-trust and fair competition laws and regulations.
content.expert_insight: This establishes a mandatory internal control process. Given the high legal risk associated with anti-trust violations, case-by-case review by Legal & Compliance is essential to tailor restrictions appropriately and avoid blanket application of potentially non-compliant clauses.
content.justification: To mitigate legal risks associated with anti-trust/competition law violations and ensure the enforceability of the restrictions.
content.implication_company: Zebracorp has a mandatory internal process to ensure legal compliance for all customer approach restrictions, protecting against significant legal and financial penalties.
content.implication_supplier: N/A
content.source_insight: N/A
content.text: Note that these restrictions must to be cleared by Legal & Compliance in each case in order to ensure that the restrictions are not in violation of any laws and regulations dealing with anti-trust/fair competition.
